title: Keeps hot stuff hot

I've tried several different ways to store hot water and this carafe is the first one to do as advertised. The last carafe I tried kept water hot for about 30 minutes, and the thermoses I used for several years might keep water hot for a few hours, and might not... usually not.
Finally, this Tiken carafe keeps my water hot all night so that when I pour it in the morning, it's piping hot. Not hot enough to make tea, but that's not my priority. I drink hot water all year 'round, but especially in winter.
There was a funny taste on the first couple of uses but that quickly resolved. The mouth of the carafe is a bit small to clean with anything other than a bottle brush, but since I only put hot water in my carafe, it's not an issue. Those who use theirs for coffee or broth may have a bit of a challenge, especially with flavors being absorbed into the silicone seal. title: Keeps liquids HOT (see my "Note")
body:
I need to have HOT water on hand due to a health issue that causes a chronic dry cough and this insulated thermal hot liquid carafe is exactly what I've needed. It's handsome to look at... kind of important to me since I keep it beside me... and extremely well made. Best part is it keeps my hot water HOT for at least 9 hours if filled "off the boil" and a solid 15-18 hours if brought to a full boil (after 15 hours, water will be HOT, but not scalding).

Just before going to bed, I always take the lid off and turn the carafe upside down on a small rack to dry over night. All in all, I'm quite happy with my "Tiken Thermal Insulated Vacuum Coffee Carafe"
and wish I'd bought it yonks ago.

Note:
The water in the carafe stays hotter MUCH longer if you fill it with HOT tap water to pre-heat it while you're bringing your kettle to a full boil. Then just empty your pre-warmed carafe out when you're ready to fill it with your boiling water. Also be sure to put the lid on properly. While that sounds like a no-brainer, apparently one user found their water cooling off way too fast either due to the lid not being on all the way allowing heat to escape OR the pour spout was somehow left open (it should auto close when you take your thumb off).
